article:
'P. Scott Makela' (1960â1999) was a graphic designer, multimedia designer and
type designer. Among other work, he was especially noted for the
design of Dead History, a postmodern typeface (issued by the Emigre digital type
foundry) that combined features of a rounded sans serif typeface and a crisp neo-
classical serif typeface. With the emergence of the personal computer in the mid-
1980s, Makela was among the first to explore digital programs such as Photoshop
and Adobe Illustrator. As a result, he created an idiosyncratic, original and
highly controversial design aesthetic. In particular, his disregard for clean,
modernist, problem-solving design agendasâsynonymous with contemporary corporate
graphic designâcaused much debate among powerful, old-guard designers such as
Massimo Vignelli, Paul Rand, and Henry Wolf. {{Citation
  | last = VanderLans first = Rudy author-link = Rudy VanderLans title = Fallout
  | journal = Emigre issue = 30 year = 1994 url =
  | http://www.emigre.com/Editorial.php?sect=1&id=31
 }}

Makela graduated from Minneapolis College of Art and Design in 1985. He
developed a notable body of work of graphics, film and "industrial soul" music
before his sudden death at the age of 39 in May 1999. Commercial yet highly
personal, Makela created visually aggressive work for clients such as Apple
Computer, Rossignol, Nike and Sony. Projects such as Michael Jackson's
"Scream"  and film titles for the seminal ''Fight
Club'' {{Citation
  | last = Her first = Lucy title = P. Scott Makela; was graphic designer known
  | for digital work newspaper = StarTribune date = 1999-05-14 url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-
  | 62474049.html}} {{Citation last = Strom first = Kirsten title =
  | Reading Scott Makela: The Subversion of Dyslexic Deconstruction journal =
  | Design Issues volume = 19 issue = 2 pages = 5â16 date = Spring 2003 url =
  | http://www.mitpressjournals.org/doi/abs/10.1162/074793603765201370 doi =
  | 10.1162/074793603765201370 id = }} defined a post-modern moment in
  | graphic design, along with the work of contemporaries such as April Greiman
  | and David Carson.

In 1996, Makela and partner and wife, Laurie Haycock Makela became designers-in-
residence and co-directors of the graduate program in Graphic Design at
Cranbrook Academy of Art in Michigan, where they also ran their studio, Words +
Pictures for Business + Culture. {{Citation
  | last = Heller first = Steven author-link =Steven Heller title = P. Scott
  | Makela, 39, Pioneering Graphic Designer, Dies newspaper = New York Times
  | date = 1999-05-15 url = http://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9504-
  | EFDF163EF936A25756C0A96F958260}}
Together with writer Lewis Blackwell they authored Whereishere (Ginko Press) an
"unprecedented print-website concept that broke from the orthodox approach to
understanding two dimensional design." {{Citation
  | last = Makela first = P. Scott coauthors = Makela, Laurie Haycock,
  | Blackwell, Lewis title = Whereishere publisher = Ginko Press year = 1998
  | isbn = 978-3-927258-87-7}}

 As a passionate snowboarder and mountain biker, Makela epitomized and
expressed early 1990s American youth culture. {{Citation
  | last = Hall first = Peter title = 365: AIGA Year in Design chapter = Truly,
  | madly, deeply: Laurie Haycock and Scott Makela chapterurl = http://www.aiga-
  | .org/resources/content/1/3/4/5/documents/haycockmakelaessay.pdf publisher =
  | AIGA year = 2001 volume = 21 isbn =978-1-884081-01-9 }}

Makela's obituary was penned by design critic Steven Heller for the New York
Times. Makela's graphic design was featured in design
magazines around the world including ''Eye'' magazine (No. 12, Vol. 3,
1994). {{Citation
  | last = Poynor first = Rick author-link = Rick Poynor journal = Eye volume =
  | 3 issue = 12 year = 1994 publisher = Wordsearch Ltd location = London url =
  | http://www.eyemagazine.com/issue.php?id=43
}}  Makela and Haycock-Makela were the co-recipients of an AIGA
Medal in 2000.

In 2013, Haycock Makela presented "Dead History: an era, a typeface and a love
story" about her late husband and their work together at Minneapolis College of
Art and Design [https://vimeo.com/64155633] and Cranbrook Academy of Art [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tP-
pZyLNr7E].
